Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my computer screen, feeling the familiar tug of anxiety. In ten minutes, our weekly team meeting would start—a routine catch-up where my manager expected everyone to show up and contribute. Even though the meeting would be recorded, I knew my absence would be noticed, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged to my colleagues. At the same time, I had registered for a national continuing education webinar, scheduled at exactly the same time. As a pharmacist, staying updated is not just a personal goal but a professional necessity; missing this session meant falling behind on the latest treatment protocols and risking my licensure requirements. My inbox pinged with a reminder from HR about the importance of team participation, while another notification popped up from the pharmacy board about the critical nature of this education program. I felt torn, my mind racing with the weight of both expectations—my team counting on my presence, my profession demanding my growth. I stared at my calendar, heart pounding, caught between two worlds that both needed me, unsure which demand to honor.
